history.content: Your internship is a pretty great opportunity especially right now when it's hard to get offers. However I would not do both a full time internship and course at the same time as that might be brutal. Ideally I'd want the extra time to focus on my internship, building good relationship and getting that return offer. I don't think you'd miss out much taking next spring off as it would be mostly online anyway.

children.subject: Thanks that helps. Since next semester is going to be remote, it seems like most of the cons mentioned aren't really going to be a factor.
you might find this video helpful!

What are you planning on taking to round out your schedule? I think I could handle 189, but I would have to take another technical class to meet the CoE policies, lest I get an enrollment delay for next fall.

Just curious, if you do plan on doing 189 will you still be paying full tuition? I will also be working 40/hr+ at a big tech company in the spring, and am considering withdrawing for the semester but a lot of my friends mentioned that internships aren't actually as time-consuming as classes.
not OP but I was also considering withdrawing ^.

@helix and Akshit: Since I don't qualify for reduced course load I'll probably end up paying full tuition—planning on doing 189 + some low workload classes. I also think internships aren't going to be as time-consuming, so my plan is to enroll in classes and do the internship; a few weeks in, if I think I won't be able to handle both, then I'll withdraw from the semester and get some of my tuition money back
Planning on doing 189 and a big tech internship as well, and know quite a few people who did similar stuff in the fall. I think it should be quite doable if you budget your time well.

history.content:
Been debating whether I should 1) take an internship for spring & withdraw, 2) take classes & have no internship, or 3) both internship + classes

The internship is fully remote, full time, and paid for a big company, so I think this is a really good opportunity to get work experience while still being able to hang out with my friends in our apartment. Work tends to be pretty chill compared to taking classes, in my experience. The alternative is taking classes (I have some classes I want to take to prep for possible research/future jobs—namely 189 and 188 (AI/ML) stuff. Otherwise, I would have to push these classes back to fall, which would be my senior year and a little late for that.

The middle ground I was considering is taking one tech I'm interested in (maybe 189), and fill up the rest of my schedule with easy or PNP-able classes. I'm a little concerned about the time commitment though (40hr/wk internship + pretty heavy class).

For reference, I'm taking 3 techs this semester + extracurriculars + spent a lot of time recruiting and still doing fine (I feel like I've adapted pretty well to online school). Have been able to do well in classes avging 2-3 techs per semester so far. Any advice is really appreciated!!

edit:: I don't qualify for any of the reduced unit things, so I'll have to take 12 units. I've already picked out 189+one very easy tech+PNP H/SS classes for schedule for next spring, in case I do both.
history.subject: Semester off for internship?
